here is something for all you dumb atheists
 
 One day a 6 year old girl was sitting in a classroom. The teacher was going to explain evolution to the children. 
 The teacher asked a little boy: Tommy do you see the tree outside? 
 TOMMY: Yes. 
 TEACHER: Tommy, do you see the grass outside? 
 TOMMY: Yes. 
 TEACHER: Go outside and look up and see if you can see the sky. 
 TOMMY: Okay. (He returned a few minutes later) Yes, I saw the sky. 
 TEACHER: Did you see God? 
 TOMMY: No. 
 TEACHER: That is my point. 
 We can not see God because he is not there. 
 He does not exist. 
 A little girl spoke up and wanted to ask the boy some questions. 
 The teacher agreed and the little girl asked the boy: Tommy, 
 do you see the tree outside? 
 TOMMY: Yes. 
 LITTLE GIRL: Tommy do you see the grass outside? 
 TOMMY: Yessssss (getting tired of the questions by this time). 
 LITTLE GIRL: Did you see the sky? 
 TOMMY: Yessssss 
 LITTLE GIRL: Tommy, do you see the teacher? 
 TOMMY: Yes 
 LITTLE GIRL: Do you see her brain? 
 TOMMY: No 
 LITTLE GIRL: Then according to what we were taught today in school, 
 she must not have one!

Bad comparison.
 
 There is a difference between beleiving that someone has a brain and beleiving that someone has a purple unicorn living in their backyard.

While I'm at it I'd like to anaylze the material presented:
 
 First off this is a classical theist / Chrisitan story for the purpose of advocating the idea of God. This can be used from Sunday school to email forwards.
 
 The average one hearing this gathers the point that just because its not seen doesn't mean its not there and moves on without much further thought.
 
 Notice how the story uses a teacher. The teacher is often considered to be intelligent and knowing. Also the teacher is given much respect by kids who this is a classical story for. So when the teacher is defied by the "little girl" without a futher response from the teacher the readers assume that the point is true and that the teacher has no response.
 
 The boy is referred to as "tommy" while (whoever) is referred to as "little girl".
 The picture of a little girl adds innocence to the idea implying that her point is simple without requiring much thought. 
 
 The story leaves off with the "little girl" establishing a weak theist point without giving the teacher / atheist a chance to respond.
 
 As for the theist point:
 
 "Just because you don't see it, doesn't mean its not there"
 
 As I have said its a bad comparison. The beleif in that I you or I have a brain can be reached by using logic and evidence. There is much more logic and evidence to support the existance of a brain than there is to support the evidence of God.

why are many of you having problems undersanding what atheism means?
 
 Most people seem to think there are only 3 diffrent positions
 
 Theism: belief in (my) God.
 Agnosticism: don't know if any gods exist.
 Atheism: denial of (my) God.
 
 but this is wrong if you take a look at what the words mean
 
 Theism, broadly defined, is simply the belief in the existence of at least one god. Contrasted with this is atheism, broadly defined, it is the absence of belief in the existence of any gods. 
 
 Gnosticism, broadly defined is simply to have knowledge in something. Contrasted with this is Agnosticism, broadly defined, is to have no knowledge in something.
 
 so the four postitions are:
 Agnostic Theism: belief in a god(s) without claiming to know for sure that god(s) exists.
 Gnostic Theism: belief in a god(s) while being certain that this god(s) exists.
 Agnostic Atheism: disbelief in gods without claiming to know for sure that none exist.
 Gnostic Atheism: disbelief in gods while being certain that none (can or do) exist.
 
 Agnostic Atheists are also knowen as Weak Atheists and Gnostic Atheists are also knowen as Strong Atheists.
 
 i myself am a Weak Atheist (aka Agnostic Atheist)

While your definitions certainly make sense, Mackers, and have a certain etymological purity about them; they follow neither the common or historical meanings of the word. Atheism is belief in no god (no comment on certainty made), Theism is belief in god (or gods, as appropriate), Agnosticism was started by a group of French Intellectuals who basically want to avoid the whole issue, their original position was 'No Knowledge of God Until Death'. They mainained that the question of God's existence or not was unanswerable by the living, and that there was no meaningful discussion to be had from the subject.
 
 I consider their position to be nothing more than intellectual cowardice.

here is something for all you dumb atheists
 
 One day a 6 year old girl was sitting in a classroom. The teacher was going to explain evolution to the children. 
 The teacher asked a little boy: Tommy do you see the tree outside? 
 TOMMY: Yes. 
 TEACHER: Tommy, do you see the grass outside? 
 TOMMY: Yes. 
 TEACHER: Go outside and look up and see if you can see the sky. 
 TOMMY: Okay. (He returned a few minutes later) Yes, I saw the sky. 
 TEACHER: Did you see God? 
 TOMMY: No. 
 TEACHER: That is my point. 
 We can not see God because he is not there. 
 He does not exist. 
 A little girl spoke up and wanted to ask the boy some questions. 
 The teacher agreed and the little girl asked the boy: Tommy, 
 do you see the tree outside? 
 TOMMY: Yes. 
 LITTLE GIRL: Tommy do you see the grass outside? 
 TOMMY: Yessssss (getting tired of the questions by this time). 
 LITTLE GIRL: Did you see the sky? 
 TOMMY: Yessssss 
 LITTLE GIRL: Tommy, do you see the teacher? 
 TOMMY: Yes 
 LITTLE GIRL: Do you see her brain? 
 TOMMY: No 
 LITTLE GIRL: Then according to what we were taught today in school, 
 she must not have one!

One day a 6 year old girl was sitting in a classroom. The teacher was going to explain Creationism to the children. 
 The teacher asked a little boy: Tommy do you see the ants turning into elephants? 
 TOMMY: No. 
 TEACHER: Tommy, do you see information increasing? 
 TOMMY: Umm I dunno?!. 
 TEACHER: Go outside and look up and see if you can see information increasing. 
 TOMMY: Okay. (He returned a few minutes later confused) No I guess not... 
 TEACHER: Did you see a bird give birth to a dinosaur? 
 TOMMY: No. 
 TEACHER: That is my point. We can not see my made up version of evolution because it is not there. Evolution therefore does not exist. 
 
 A little girl spoke up and wanted to ask the boy some questions. 
 The teacher agreed and the little girl asked the boy: Tommy, 
 do you see the transitional fossils in the museum? 
 TOMMY: Yes. 
 LITTLE GIRL: Tommy do you see genetic homology in species? 
 TOMMY: Yessssss (getting tired of the questions by this time). 
 LITTLE GIRL: Did you see examples of beneficial mutation? 
 TOMMY: Yessssss 
 LITTLE GIRL: Tommy, don't you think the teacher is therefore brainwashing us with religious based pseudoscientific distortions of the truth?
 TOMMY: Yea lets get outta here

here is something for all you dumb atheists
 
 One day a 6 year old girl was sitting in a classroom. The teacher was going to explain evolution to the children. 
 The teacher asked a little boy: Tommy do you see the tree outside? 
 TOMMY: Yes. 
 TEACHER: Tommy, do you see the grass outside? 
 TOMMY: Yes. 
 TEACHER: Go outside and look up and see if you can see the sky. 
 TOMMY: Okay. (He returned a few minutes later) Yes, I saw the sky. 
 TEACHER: Did you see God? 
 TOMMY: No. 
 TEACHER: That is my point. 
 We can not see God because he is not there. 
 He does not exist. 
 A little girl spoke up and wanted to ask the boy some questions. 
 The teacher agreed and the little girl asked the boy: Tommy, 
 do you see the tree outside? 
 TOMMY: Yes. 
 LITTLE GIRL: Tommy do you see the grass outside? 
 TOMMY: Yessssss (getting tired of the questions by this time). 
 LITTLE GIRL: Did you see the sky? 
 TOMMY: Yessssss 
 LITTLE GIRL: Tommy, do you see the teacher? 
 TOMMY: Yes 
 LITTLE GIRL: Do you see her brain? 
 TOMMY: No 
 LITTLE GIRL: Then according to what we were taught today in school, 
 she must not have one!

As a card carrying atheist, I am often bemused by the lines we all draw over our disagreements. Any issue short of the existence of god is nothing but a distraction to me.
 
 The issue is quite simply do you have faith or not. If you don't you will never understand those that do and if you do you will never understand those that don't. The real issue then becomes how does it matter.
 
 I typically only enter an argument when I feel that my individual right to this conclusion is being subjugated to the will of others. I do not resent the proclamation, ecumenism or downright missionary zeal of the faithful. I do resent the unwillingness for other views to be proferred.
 
 All I know is that until science has answered all the questions, there will be a substantial reason for people to carry faith. I only fear the reality of jihad's and crusades. If these behaviour ever become the norm in modern society, I will have to have to take a more activist position.
